articles.headline: Demand Up, U.S. Economy Shows Gains
articles.snippet: New data suggests an increased demand by businesses for manufactured goods in July, as well as rising consumer confidence.
articles.abstract: New data suggests an increased demand by businesses for manufactured goods in July, as well as rising consumer confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy is gaining renewed momentum, with data released on Tuesday suggesting strong demand by businesses for airplanes, machinery and other manufactured items, as well as rising confidence among consumers, despite a cooling in the housing market.

articles.headline: American Fighting for ISIS Is Killed in Syria
articles.snippet: Douglas McAuthur McCain’s death is an early clue for American officials as they try to identify the Americans who have joined ISIS.
articles.abstract: Douglas McAuthur McCain’s death is an early clue for American officials as they try to identify the Americans who have joined ISIS.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like many teenage boys who grew up in the Midwest in the 1990s, Douglas McAuthur McCain was a fan of Michael Jordan’s Chicago Bulls and loved to play basketball.

articles.headline: Tech Tenants Filling a Slice of Brooklyn Called Dumbo Heights
articles.snippet: The Jehovah’s Witnesses have moved their headquarters upstate, and their Watchtower complex in Dumbo is attracting tech start-ups.
articles.abstract: The Jehovah’s Witnesses have moved their headquarters upstate, and their Watchtower complex in Dumbo is attracting tech start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the leading gospels coming out of Brooklyn over the last century has been that of Jehovah’s Witnesses.

articles.headline: Detroit Mum on Proposal to Use Its Art as Collateral
articles.snippet: A confidential report to the bankrupt city offers a loan of $500 million to $3 billion, collateralized by pieces in the Detroit Institute of Arts, at a rate of Libor plus 5.5 to 8.5 percentage points.
articles.abstract: A confidential report to the bankrupt city offers a loan of $500 million to $3 billion, collateralized by pieces in the Detroit Institute of Arts, at a rate of Libor plus 5.5 to 8.5 percentage points.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, there is the art of the deal. In Detroit, there is the deal of the art.

articles.headline: Speed and Spectators Led to Twitch, a Gaming Nexus
articles.snippet: Twitch.tv, bought by Amazon for over $1 billion, flourished with increasing data speeds and a growing community, taking over the start-up that created it.
articles.abstract: Twitch.tv, bought by Amazon for over $1 billion, flourished with increasing data speeds and a growing community, taking over the start-up that created it.
articles.lead_paragraph: To call Twitch.tv a happy accident would be a grand understatement.

articles.headline: As Online Video Surges, the .TV Domain Rides the Wave
articles.snippet: The domain, owned by Tuvalu, a tiny South Pacific island nation, signals how people watch TV now — online and on apps — and makes the country a tidy sum, too.
articles.abstract: The domain, owned by Tuvalu, a tiny South Pacific island nation, signals how people watch TV now — online and on apps — and makes the country a tidy sum, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of the dot-com boom. Is the dot-tv boom next?

articles.headline: U.S. Mobilizes Allies to Widen Assault on ISIS
articles.snippet: President Obama is nearing a decision to authorize airstrikes and airdrops around Amerli, an Iraqi town that has been under siege by militants for more than two months.
articles.abstract: President Obama is nearing a decision to authorize airstrikes and airdrops around Amerli, an Iraqi town that has been under siege by militants for more than two months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has begun to mobilize a broad coalition of allies behind potential American military action in Syria and is moving toward expanded airstrikes in northern Iraq, administration officials said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Obama Pursuing Climate Accord in Lieu of Treaty
articles.snippet: To sidestep Senate approval, President Obama’s negotiators are devising what they call a “politically binding” deal to “name and shame” countries into cutting their emissions.
articles.abstract: To sidestep Senate approval, President Obama’s negotiators are devising what they call a “politically binding” deal to “name and shame” countries into cutting their emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is working to forge a sweeping international climate change agreement to compel nations to cut their planet-warming fossil fuel emissions, but without ratification from Congress.

articles.headline: In Aftermath of Missouri Protests, Skepticism About the Prospects for Change
articles.snippet: Though the shooting of Michael Brown turned a few blocks of suburban St. Louis into disputed territory, many local protesters emphasized that their grievances with the police are common throughout the area.
articles.abstract: Though the shooting of Michael Brown turned a few blocks of suburban St. Louis into disputed territory, many local protesters emphasized that their grievances with the police are common throughout the area.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAPLEWOOD, Mo. — On Monday night, just a few hours after Michael Brown was laid to rest, an amiable judge sat in the City Council chambers here and weighed in on the traffic violations and petty crimes, one by one, of more than a hundred people. At least two-thirds of those waiting were black, roughly a reverse racial image of the demographics of Maplewood itself.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: Gift-Bearing Officials Try to Lure Chinese Factories Inland
articles.snippet: With foreign investment falling, inland provinces are in a cutthroat competition to attract local industries.
articles.abstract: With foreign investment falling, inland provinces are in a cutthroat competition to attract local industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Renley Watch Manufacturing Company is one of the companies that helped coastal southeastern China displace Switzerland as the center of the world’s watchmaking industry. But now Renley, like many watchmakers, is mulling whether to move far into China’s interior.
